verses.text: When human beings began to multiply on the face of the earth and daughters were born to them,
verses.comment: The growth of humanity sets the stage for the events to follow, echoing the command to 'be fruitful and multiply.' This increase leads to new challenges for righteousness.

verses.text: the sons of God saw that the daughters of man were beautiful, and they took wives for themselves, anyone they chose.
verses.comment: The phrase 'sons of God' has been interpreted in various ways, including angelic or righteous descendants of Seth. The pattern of taking wives 'anyone they chose' hints at the disorder and moral decline present before the flood.

verses.text: Then the LORD said, 'My Spirit will not strive with man forever, for he is flesh; his days shall be one hundred and twenty years.'
verses.comment: The limit of one hundred and twenty years may refer to a lifespan bound or the time until the coming flood. God's Spirit strives with humanity, an early hint at the divine presence working through salvation history.

verses.text: The Nephilim were on the earth in those days—and also afterward—when the sons of God came in to the daughters of man and bore children to them. These were the mighty men who were of old, men of renown.
verses.comment: The Nephilim are mysterious figures associated with great strength. Their presence indicates a distortion in the order of creation before the flood, providing context for God's judgment.

verses.text: The LORD saw that the wickedness of man was great on the earth, and every intention of the thoughts of his heart was only evil continually.
verses.comment: The inner corruption of humanity is emphasized—all thoughts were evil. Human sin is not superficial but deep-rooted. This total depravity underscores the need for divine intervention and redemption.

verses.text: And the LORD was grieved that he had made man on the earth, and his heart was deeply troubled.
verses.comment: The language of grief and trouble shows God's personal engagement with creation, not distant or cold. Theologically, this anthropomorphic description points towards a God who feels, prefiguring Christ's compassion (cf. John 11:35).

verses.text: So the LORD said, 'I will blot out man whom I have created from the face of the earth—man and animals and creeping things and birds of the heavens—for I am grieved that I have made them.'
verses.comment: God's declaration to destroy creation highlights both judgment and sorrow. Not only humans, but all creatures linked to them, are swept up in the consequences of sin, showing the interconnectedness of creation.

verses.text: But Noah found favor in the eyes of the LORD.
verses.comment: Noah is singled out for grace—the concept of being chosen by God amidst general judgment foreshadows themes of election and divine mercy found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: These are the generations of Noah. Noah was a righteous man, blameless among his generation. Noah walked with God.
verses.comment: Noah's righteousness and walking with God echo the language used of Enoch. True righteousness involves relationship, not just right actions. This 'walking' may subtly prefigure later teachings of abiding in God.

verses.text: Noah fathered three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
verses.comment: The naming of Noah's sons sets the foundation for future nations and genealogies, which will play a large role in salvation history.

verses.text: Now the earth was corrupt in God's sight, and the earth was filled with violence.
verses.comment: The repeated emphasis on corruption and violence illustrates the extent of sin and echoes the consequences first seen with Cain.

verses.text: God looked upon the earth, and indeed, it was corrupt; for all flesh had corrupted their way on the earth.
verses.comment: Universal corruption is highlighted—'all flesh.' This prepares for the sweeping judgment to come, and points to God's justice, balanced by His subsequent mercy to Noah.

verses.text: And God said to Noah, 'I have determined to make an end of all flesh, for the earth is filled with violence through them; behold, I will destroy them along with the earth.'
verses.comment: God communicates directly to Noah, revealing His plan. This is one of the earliest examples of divine revelation to a chosen individual, anticipating later instances of prophetic calling.

verses.text: 'Make yourself an ark of cypress wood. Make rooms in the ark, and cover it inside and out with pitch.'
verses.comment: The instructions for the ark foreshadow later patterns of sacred construction—like the tabernacle. The use of pitch for protection is symbolically reminiscent of spiritual safeguarding by God's grace.

verses.text: 'This is how you shall make it: the ark shall be three hundred cubits long, fifty cubits wide, and thirty cubits high.'
verses.comment: Detailed, ordered measurements reinforce the importance of obedience to God's commands. The form and structure also reflect the later biblical focus on divinely-instituted order in worship and community.

verses.text: 'Make a roof for the ark, and finish it to a cubit above; put a door in the side of the ark, and make lower, second, and third decks.'
verses.comment: Provision of divisions, a single entrance, and structure prefigures salvation’s uniqueness and ordering—Christ as the 'door' (cf. John 10:9) through whom redemption comes.

verses.text: 'For behold, I will bring a flood of waters upon the earth to destroy all flesh in which is the breath of life under heaven. Everything that is on the earth shall die.'
verses.comment: God’s total sovereignty over life and death is revealed. This judgment is both temporal and spiritual, being a sign of God’s just reaction to sin but also His preparation for a new creation in peace.

verses.text: 'But I will establish my covenant with you. You shall come into the ark—you, your sons, your wife, and your sons' wives with you.'
verses.comment: God’s mention of 'covenant' is pivotal—the first use of the word in Scripture. Commitment to Noah and household prefigures the idea of household salvation and the continuity of the family in the plan of redemption.

verses.text: 'And of every living thing of all flesh, you shall bring two of every kind into the ark to keep them alive with you. They shall be male and female.'
verses.comment: God's concern for all creation is shown here. The preservation of male and female strengthens the biblical witness for ordered complementarity, and points to redemption extending beyond humanity.

verses.text: 'Of the birds according to their kinds, and of the animals according to their kinds, of every creeping thing of the ground according to its kind, two of every sort shall come to you to keep them alive.'
verses.comment: The ordered diversity of creation is reflected. The animals ‘come to Noah,’ showing God’s sovereignty even over the creatures—a sign of providence.

verses.text: 'Also take with you every sort of food that is eaten, and store it up. It shall serve as food for you and for them.'
verses.comment: Noah is entrusted to provide food for all on the ark, highlighting stewardship, preparation, and obedience, which are hallmarks of faith working through love.

verses.text: Noah did everything just as God commanded him.
verses.comment: Obedience completes the chapter—Noah’s response to grace is faith expressed in action. This anticipates later biblical teachings about salvation by faith that works through obedience—a unity manifested in God's people through the ages.
